title: 114_hr4386
content: The "Pathways to an Affordable Education Act" includes provisions such as increasing the Federal Pell Grant, funding the program through mandatory appropriations, and adding a cost of living adjustment. It also addresses grant duration limits, eligibility restoration for year-round grants, and early communication about Pell Grant availability. The "Pathways to an Affordable Education Act" includes increasing the Federal Pell Grant amount annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The amendment increases the Federal Pell Grant amount annually based on the Consumer Price Index, effective for awards starting in 2017-2018 and beyond. The Federal Pell Grant program will be funded through mandatory appropriations. The Federal Pell Grant program will receive necessary appropriations from the Treasury to provide grants to eligible students starting from fiscal year 2017. The amendments made by subsection (a) will take effect immediately. The amendments made by subsection (a) will apply to Federal Pell Grants awarded for the 2017-2018 award year and beyond. SEC. 4. MANDATORY FEDERAL PELL GRANT INCREASES. SEC. 4 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates increases in the Federal Pell Grant amount. This includes adjustments to paragraph (2) and the addition of a new paragraph at the end. The Federal Pell Grant amount is increased by the difference between the average total cost of attendance for first-time, full-time undergraduate students at public 2-year institutions and the maximum Pell Grant amount for an eligible student during an award year. This adjustment is mandated by SEC. 4 of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply to Federal Pell Grants awarded for award year 2017-2018 and each succeeding award year for eligible students with negative or zero estimated family contribution. SEC. 5 amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to extend the duration limit for Federal Pell Grants from 12 to 15 semesters. The amendment applies to grants awarded for the 2017-2018 award year and beyond. SEC. 6 allows for the restoration of eligibility for year-round Federal Pell Grants. The amendment to the Higher Education Act of 1965 extends the duration limit for Federal Pell Grants from 12 to 15 semesters. Additionally, eligible students can now receive an additional Federal Pell Grant for extra payment periods during the same award year. To be eligible for an additional Federal Pell Grant, a student must be enrolled at least half-time for more than one academic year or equivalent, and in a program at an institution that awards degrees or certificates. In the case of a student receiving multiple Federal Pell Grants in a single award year, the total amount awarded cannot exceed 150 percent of the maximum Pell Grant amount for which the student is eligible. Any period covered by a Pell Grant is included in determining a student's duration limit. The amendment allows eligible institutions to determine the award year for a student receiving a Federal Pell Grant spanning 2 award years. Effective July 1, 2017. SEC. 7 expands the Pell Grant exclusion from gross income for qualified tuition and related expenses. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2015. SEC. 8 introduces early communication for Federal Pell Grants. Section 485E of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include elementary schools in subsection (a) and expand notification requirements to students and parents of students in subsection (b) for both elementary and secondary schools. Section 485E of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include elementary schools in subsection (a) and expand notification requirements to students and parents of students in subsection (b) for both elementary and secondary schools. Additionally, changes are made to specify that the notification requirements apply to students in sixth grade instead of junior year of secondary school. SEC. 9. CONTRIBUTION FROM ADJUSTED AVAILABLE INCOME. Amendments to sections 475(b), 476(a), and 477(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 involve inserting new language regarding exceptions for purposes other than subpart 1 of part A of the title. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply to award year 2017-2018 and each succeeding award year.
